name: Anonymous
com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9487391
>>9487464
>>9487493
This happened before too, the best example being how it got reflected in 1940s comic books. In the early 40s, comic books were load and flashy and aggressive, full of colorful superheroes murdering nazis. Then the war ended, people wanted to put it behind them, and this kind of violent punchy action stuff felt a lot less appealing. Audiences wanted lighthearted and inoffensive fun, and comedic light drama like Archie took over for the superheroes. Then the pendulum started swinging the other way and audiences wanted more realistic and "edgy" stuff - not superheroes, which were always really fantastic and larger than life, but gritty and brutal crime and horror, as well as war comics that showed the dirty reality of war instead of glorifying it and shitting on the enemy.

What your typical rando thought of when he heard the phrase "comic book" in the early 40s was Captain America, in the late 40s it was Archie, and in the early 50s it was Crime Does Not Pay. Three very very different books that had extreme mass appeal during their respective biggest eras.

>>9487436
This is a great question, and I'll try to answer it from my own point of view. Personally, I feel that the only games that have ever tried to imitate Resident Evil are its own series, and Dino Crisis 1. This is even debatable, as truthfully the only REAL survival horror games, as in games that both combine survival AND horror, without going down the more action heavy route, are RE1, REmake, and Dino Crisis.

Back to the subject though, you'll notice all of REs knock-offs barely ever tried to imitate its style. Even Silent Hill, its greatest rip-off, is absolutely nothing like Resident Evil. It has virtually no item management, and ammo is not scarce at all. Most of the games just try to rip off its camera angle and let you shoot monsters. But how many tried to copy the Mansion, or added in interesting, well-thought backtracking? How many are actually scarce on ammunition, or force you to really strategize how you go through each room? It just doesn't exist. I'm not sure if Resident Evil was just that good, or the developers were just flat out lazy and all of the clones were cash grabs. But they aren't very good in comparison, and they all lack polish.

>>9487551
>but it seems to tick all the boxes of the actual definition
youre a literally retarded NPC

the *actual*, real thing that separates a "survival horror" game from something else is the true permanence of consequence, aka putting the onus of survival onto the player regardless of how easy or hard it is to achieve in actuality

RE1 is a survival horror game because it has truly finite resources and if you choose to shoot them onto a wall the game wont take pity on you and divine more resources from some enemys asshole, unlike RE4, dead space or the evil within

Call of Cthulhu DCOTE has light elements of survival horror but it doesnt commit into the design in its linear gauntlet that doesnt leave much space for consistent systems or long term consequences to ever really unlock the meaning of the label

RE4 is an action game and any type of mild (perceived) resource scarcity in that game only exists to incentivize actually interacting with the full action mechanics of the game (conserving resources by hitting weakspots and using the melee to either hit entire crowds or immediately damage one enemy as much as possible, using the knife, using the environmental tools) instead of just unloading into the crowd which would completely break the encounter design

I don't think softlocks are ever really good design, without a clear fail condition they can leave the player wondering if they never figured out the answer to something and unsure if they messed something up or not. I remember one of the worst times I encountered a softlock was getting to the final boss of Resident Evil Dead Aim and realizing I didn't have enough ammo to actually finish him off even with hitting every single remaining bullet. I didn't have a recent save I could go back to and scavenge more ammo in, nor do I think there was ammo left in the world to scavenge anyway. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9484950

A big part of their business model in those days was to make money on selling publishers the cartridge media; and it was also the primary anti-piracy measure. Early computer systems like the Commodore, Specturm etc had absurdly easy piracy because you could just copy the cassettes on your hi-fi. Console bootleg cartirdges existed but it was nothing like the explosion of piracy once chipped PS1s became commonplace and you could just copy a game you rented from Blockbuster onto a blank CD-R. That's when the business model changed, with Sony selling hardware at a loss and making it's money on the game licensing- It can bee argued N64 was less successful because they missed the boat on that.

To this day they still typically sell hardware on a loss- with the difference that since the advent of online distribution they can much more easily recoup the losses because they monopolise the actual marketplace.

This is a lot of the reason the games industry is such a shitshow, by the way. It's like the music industry on crack. It's all built on skimming off the fat and squeezing profits out of the people who actually MAKE the product, then fucking them over and throwing them in the trash.

>solder chips

>>9483467
>Memes aside, when did you find out?

That's a good question, because i don't even remember. As a kid the first time I saw SMB2 was at an arcade (yes, an arcade) that also sold NES games at the front counter. And they had a TV set with a NES set up that was playing Mario Bros. 2. They would let people try the game out if you asked. I would rent the game, but never owned it. I owned SMB1, SMB3, and SMW, but never SMB2. Super Mario Bros. 2 did stand out as being a little different from the other games in the series. As a kid, I thought SMB3 was a step backwards from SMB2 in many ways. Ni selectable characters, no being able to pick up anything and throw it. Though the game did add the ability to pick up some objects. But at the same time, I never really suspected that it was a different game. because Zelda II on the NES was different from the first Zelda as well. Plus Nintendo did a good job adapting the characters from SMB2 into the Mario cannon. Also, the Super Mario Bros Super Show was on TV around the same time, which used a lot of characters from SMB2, but no Wart.

>>SMB2 (J) was considered too difficult for western kids/gamers
>That's just a meme. NoA didn't want to release it because they thought an expert level pack would be a tough sell. Especially when renting is a thing and you can easily satisfy your curiosity of what "harder Mario" is by just renting it once.

The Japanese Super Mario Bros. 2 was sold as a Disk system game in Japan, and was marketed to the Japanese as hard mode Mario Bros. But in 1987-1988, the game did look dated for a NES game in comparison to the other third party NES games from Konami and Capcom. It looked way too much like the first game. Doki Doki Panic did look better overall, and wasn't geared towards a hard mode. Localising it was the best thing to do. It was a game made by EAD. Also, because Doki Doki Panic was part of a special event in Japan, Nintendo did not own the characters. They did re-release Doki Doki Panic in Japan as Super Mario Bros. USA on cartridge. The original Doki Doki was on the Disk system.

idk how much you know about the profession of graphic design works. but there are a few things you have to have in mind with generally used things like fonts:
. there are many font families that are eerily similar between each other, developed by different studios for different projects etc...in any case, they will have differences even if minuscule which make them a font of its own.

. designers do not accostume on designing completely new font families for some projects, especially an area as throw-and-stick as videogame marketing. so, even if this was indeed the same font used for the american SNES logo and its marketing, the rights for it were purchased for its use by ESPN just like nintendo did back then to whomever had the rights for it
***just searched about this topic itself and apparently the marketing team handmade the logo and some of the headlines heavfily based on Univers. yet they did not develop a font family for it and just kept using Univers.

. Now, knowing what the origins of the SNES font are, the last case and one tat is quite possible for this case: some guy at ESPN found or remembered the SNES font and got one of the fonts inspired by it, which are all free use so there is no issue to be had.

Why hasn't anyone ever attempted to port Snatcher to the SEGA 32X CD?
The SEGA CD version is great, especially with the added light gun support that the PC Engine CD version lacked.
However, the SEGA CD version has much less colours and has been graphically downgraded compared to the PC Engine CD version because the Genesis can output much less colours at a time compared to the PC Engine.
There's also the issue of minor censorship in the SEGA CD version.

Restoring the uncensored content is one thing, but it would be much harder to restore the higher colour depth of the PC Engine CD to the SEGA CD without having to port it to the 32X.

>>9485062
>It couldn't do progressive 480p scan (the reason why DoA2 looks better on Dreamcast) but then it suddenly could with Tekken 5 and Gran Turismo 4.

It could do 480p, but then you were left with almost no VRAM left. Most programmers at the time expected VRAM to hold both textures and framebuffer, so they went for small framebuffer and crap textures with 4 colors.

Then years later they figured out they can write a code on the coprocessor that textured from system memory (where they had a massive lead), because the vram was so stupid fast that this was actually practical. After that you had 480p games.

name: Anonymous
com:
Most overrated game in history? I just finished this mediocre test of patience, and I have some thoughts about it that are probably gonna piss the fanboys off.

Yeah I know this is a beloved game and all, but I’m here to tell you that title has not been earned.

First off, I have to talk about the idea of difficulty for the sake of difficulty. This is objectively bad game design, as it doesn’t allow the player to meaningfully overcome challenges in a controlled manner. The difficulty of this game spikes incredibly after the first world when all of a sudden they throw this fucking mine cart mechanic at you, and it’s nearly impossible to control.

Second, there’s literally no reason for any of the levels. There’s nothing to be gained from any of them, no sub plots, no actual point to donkey Kong and diddy infiltrating factories or driving a mine cart down the rails of an abandoned mine. What’s my motivation for the levels?

Third, bonuslevels? I don’t get anything for completing them? Not like a new weapon or ability or anything? What’s the point? To watch the completion percentage number go up. Okay???

Fourth, speaking of, donkey and diddy don’t learn anything from their adventures. No new abilities, no character development, no extra knowledge that unlocks paths in the levels, they just stay the same the whole time.

Fifth, I can only get hit once!?!! I’m a giant gorilla, the king of the jungle, and I get taken out by TOUCHING A BEAVER??? Makes no fucking sense. They could have at least included a health bar. The one hit shit is nonsensical and only exists to add artificial difficulty.

Sixth. Running and jumping in every level. I can roll too. No actual attacks though. Again, king of the jungle, I should be able to rip a man in half with my bare hands, but I’m stuck doing gymnastics.

Seven, funky kong could have dropped me off at k rool right from the start. Making all of the levels pointless. Massive plot hole

name: Anonymous
com:
Someone posted this image on /ck/ and it reminded me how much I hated pre-rendered backgrounds in 3d games as a kid. Growing up with the SNES and Genesis, I remember the first game we got in 3D was Mario 64, which gives you a very physical, tactile environment where your character interacts with every surface and edge. Then you play something like Zelda or Final Fantasy of the same generation and you get these weird environments where you never feel like your character collides with anything, like your character is running around in a clear box with invisible walls and there is a background superimposed via green screen. As I got older and understood why it was made that way I appreciated the effort and extra detail allowed by it, but as a kid it always bugged me and still does to a degree.

Did this bother anyone else as a kid or just me?

last_replies.com: the pre-rendered areas in OoT are probably my favorites. i wish there had been more of them. the fact you can't fully explore them made them more interesting and mysterious; you could see but never quite touch, leaving room for the imagination. also the lenticular ones like castle town were very impressive; 360 degree pre-rendered scenes wasn't something you'd see very often. i also thought they did a good job of making the pre-rendered areas look similar enough to the fully 3D areas that the transition was believable, and they mostly used pre-rendering in places like houses that needed lots of little details and messy things to look realistic more so than the game's large open areas. very smart design. i don't know how anybody could hate these, they look cool as fuck. i suggest killing yourself OP.

I played the NES version, the SNES version and the GBC version (I even got to the boss that requires all badges in the GBC version)

The SNES version was by far the easiest one precisely due to the lower encounter rate in dungeons. GBC version is similar to SNES but at least has a decent encounter rate, although for some reasons in that version the player is allowed to use spells in the egyptian pyramid dungeon because fuck balance and original intended gameplay design right

And yes, I did get a grand total of 5 encounters in the dungeon north of the Dharma Temple in the SNES version, which on NES is what I got from a single floor.

I don't know why this surprises you so much considering that if you knew maintstream JRPGs, you'd know challenge and encounter rate went increasingly downhill with each generation. DQ3 on SNES was released well into the 5th gen, one month before Final Fantasy VII.
